Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I walked beside my stepbrother, our backpacks bouncing in rhythm as we made our way down Maple Street. Mom always said to look out for each other, and I took that seriously—especially after what happened last year. My phone buzzed in my pocket, and I glanced at the screen: a customer was asking about their package, the one I’d just realized was delayed at the depot. My heart thudded. As a delivery person, I was supposed to respond quickly and professionally, but my brother was chattering about his day, and I needed to keep an eye on him crossing the busy intersection ahead. The customer’s message pinged again, more insistent this time. I felt torn—should I stop and type out a polite, reassuring reply, risking my brother darting ahead without me? Or should I focus on him, knowing my job expected me to be responsive and courteous? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, and I hesitated, caught between the two worlds I was supposed to manage.
